factoid: Human life can be categorized by whether substance prevails or form prevails.
Petersburg life can be classified as a type of life where form prevails.
The life of Petersburg salons is an example of form-prevalent life.
The life of Petersburg salons is unchanging.
Since 1805, peace was made with Napoleon Bonaparte.
Since 1805, quarrels with Napoleon Bonaparte occurred.
Since 1805, constitutions were made.
Since 1805, constitutions were unmade.
Anna Pávlovna's salon had remained unchanged for seven years.
Hélène's salon had remained unchanged for five years.
People in Anna Pávlovna's salon talked with perplexity about Napoleon Bonaparte's successes.
People in Anna Pávlovna's salon saw a malicious conspiracy in Napoleon Bonaparte's successes and in the subservience shown to him by European sovereigns.
The malicious conspiracy's sole object was to cause unpleasantness and anxiety to the court circle represented by Anna Pávlovna.
Anna Pávlovna represented a court circle.
Rumyántsev visited Hélène's salon and honored it.
Rumyántsev regarded Hélène as a remarkably intelligent woman.
People in Hélène's salon talked with ecstasy in 1812 and 1808 about the 'great nation' and the 'great man'.
People in Hélène's salon regretted the rupture with France.
People in Hélène's salon believed the rupture with France should be promptly terminated by peace.
Since the Emperor's return from the army, excitement occurred in the conflicting salon circles.
Since the Emperor's return from the army, demonstrations of hostility between the salon circles occurred.
Each salon circle retained its own tendency.
Only deep-rooted legitimist Frenchmen were admitted to Anna Pávlovna's circle.
People in Anna Pávlovna's circle expressed that one ought not to go to the French theater.
People in Anna Pávlovna's circle expressed that maintaining the French troupe cost the government as much as a whole army corps.
People in Anna Pávlovna's circle eagerly followed the progress of the war.
People in Anna Pávlovna's circle circulated only reports most flattering to the Russian army.
In Hélène and Rumyántsev's French circle, reports of the cruelty of the enemy and of the war were contradicted.
In Hélène and Rumyántsev's French circle, all Napoleon's attempts at conciliation were discussed.
People in Hélène and Rumyántsev's circle discountenanced those who advised hurried preparations for a removal to Kazán of the court.

People in Hélène and Rumyántsev's circle discountenanced those who advised hurried preparations for a removal to Kazán of the girls’ educational establishments under the patronage of the Dowager Empress.
People in Hélène's circle regarded the war as a series of formal demonstrations that would soon end in peace.
Bilíbin, who was at home in Hélène's house in Petersburg, expressed that matters would be settled not by gunpowder but by those who invented it.
Every clever man was obliged to visit Hélène's house.
People in Hélène's circle ridiculed Moscow enthusiasm with sarcasm and cleverness, though cautiously.
People in Anna Pávlovna's circle were enraptured by Moscow enthusiasm and spoke of it as Plutarch speaks of the deeds of the ancients.
Prince Vasíli formed a connecting link between Anna Pávlovna's circle and Hélène's circle.
Prince Vasíli visited Anna Pávlovna's salon.
Prince Vasíli visited his daughter's diplomatic salon.
Prince Vasíli became confused in his comings and goings between the two circles and said at Hélène's what he should have said at Anna Pávlovna's, and vice versa.
Soon after the Emperor's return, Prince Vasíli severely condemned Barclay de Tolly in a conversation about the war at Anna Pávlovna's salon.
Prince Vasíli was undecided as to who ought to be appointed commander in chief.
A visitor, described as a man of great merit, saw Kutúzov presiding over the enrollment of recruits at the Treasury.
The visitor suggested that Kutúzov would satisfy all requirements to be appointed commander in chief.
Anna Pávlovna remarked that Kutúzov had caused the Emperor annoyance.
Prince Vasíli had talked at the Assembly of the Nobility.
Prince Vasíli said that people did not listen to Prince Vasíli.
Prince Vasíli said that Prince Vasíli had told people that Kutúzov's election as chief of the militia would not please the Emperor.
People did not listen to Prince Vasíli.
